awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Low-Temperature High-Magnetic-Field Multifunctional Scanning Probe Microscopy System
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
One of the core elements of modern science is to acquire structural information from a broad range of length scales including the scale of atoms, molecules, and nanostructures to solar systems and galaxies. Imaging methods in real space play an ever-increasing role in structure analysis. From the acquired information, it is then possible to build theoretical models that can explain the underlying phenomena. In the case of nanoscience and materials research, imaging structures and properties has led to revolutionary progress in nanotechnology, information technology, and biotechnology, particularly after the invention of electron and scanning-probe microscopy, for which Nobel prizes were awarded in 1986. This grant allows purchase of a cutting-edge microscopy system with extreme sample environments to further advance the boundary of science in terms of elucidating the underlying mechanisms of complex material properties on the nanometer scale. The outcome of the research carried out using the microscopy system is expected to have important impacts on the applications of many mechanical, electrical, magnetic, and energy materials. The microscopy system also provides training opportunities on the state-of-the-art microscopy instrument for a large group of graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers and help promote public awareness of the importance of nanoscience and nanotechnology.

Technical Description
This project acquires a state-of-the-art, multifunctional, low-temperature, high-magnetic-field scanning probe microscopy system at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and enables broad usage of the system for nanoscale science and engineering research. The system is capable of characterizing spatially resolved conductivity, magnetic force, piezoresponse force, and topography down to the nanoscale. The system is equipped with an ultra-low-vibration sample environment that offers a wide range of temperature and magnetic fields. Building on the versatile capabilities of the system, this instrument enables research projects that explore: 1) the morphology, electric transport, magnetism, and ferroelectricity on nanoscale and low-dimensional materials; 2) the coupling between these properties; 3) material properties that emerge only at extreme conditions, as well as the related thermodynamic phase transitions; and 4) quantum phase transitions in electric and/or magnetic fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

This project acquires a state-of-the-art, multifunctional scanning probe microscope system equipped with a low temperature and high magnetic field sample environment at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and enable broad usage of the system for nanoscale science and engineering research. Scanning probe microscopy employs physical probes to scan and form images of surfaces. Depending on the probe-surface interaction, difference physical properties can be imaged down to the nanoscale. The recent development of scanning-probe microcopy allows measurements in extreme conditions, while keeping the nanoscale resolution. The system has been installed in the Surface and Materials Characterization Facility of the UNL Nebraska Center for Materials and Nanoscience (NCMN) and Nebraska Nanoscale Facility (NNF) a component of the NSF-supported National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI).

This project offers training and professional development opportunities for a diverse population of researchers and outreach to the public.

Intellectual Merit:

The acquired system characterizes spatially resolved conductivity, magnetic force, piezoresponse force, and topography down to the nanoscale. The system is also equipped with an ultra-low-vibration sample environment that offers a wide range of temperature and magnetic fields. The unique capabilities of the system allow scientists and engineers to study not only nanoscale and low-dimensional morphology, electric transport, magnetism, and ferroelectricity, but also the coupling between these properties and transitions between material phases. It also enables new research capabilities in terms of studying emergent phenomena, thermodynamic and quantum phase transitions at the nanoscale. Within the project period, in addition to setting up the system, the project contributed to advancing our understandings in structure, magneto transport, and magnetoelectric couplings in thin film materials. For example: using the system, researchers have demonstrated:

  • Magnetic bubble domain appears in a magnetic thin film of in-plane anisotropy at low temperature in magnetic field which coincides with the appearance of topological Hall effect. The combination of magnetic imaging and magneto transport points to the emergence of chiral spin texture upon magnetization switching.
  • The magnetic domain wall thickness is much larger than that of the ferroelectric domain wall of multiferroic hexagonal ferrites, suggesting possibility of magnetoelectric coupling at the clamped ferroelectric and magnetic domain wall.
  • Topological structural defects in hexagonal material that has a significant impact on the local magnetic texture.

Broader Impacts:

The acquired system has been a unique resource for NCMN and NNCI, which are responsible to provide state-of-the-art instrumentation to both University of Nebraska and external university and company scientists and engineers. The highly versatile system enables a wide range of new and innovative research and education activities, allowing scientists and engineers to tackle fundamental problems at the nanoscale. The system has enhanced the University?s strongest collaborative research programs such as the MRSEC, EQUATE, and other research programs supported by NSF and DOE.

The acquired system has trigger an effort at UNL in developing quantum-sensing based scanning probe microscopy in extreme conditions, taking advantage of the low temperature and high magnetic field of the sample environment the system.

The acquisition of the system has been an important factor in attracting new faculty members, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. The project has trained multiple researchers, including the instrument specialist and graduate students on the technique of scanning probe and the operation of the system.
